One, Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, saying granting immunity to people who have killed Americans is not acceptable, and I don't - and here's the interesting language here, and this comes from Mr. McConnell after hearing from the Prime Minister of Iraq.

SUÁREZ-OROZCO: Well, in the context of the history of the last century, indeed, the number of casualties is much smaller in proportion to what we've seen in - certainly World War II, Vietnam, Korea, and so on.
The question is really in terms of the Iraqi proposal, and why it is somewhat unorthodox, is that in general, amnesties tend to come to the table in the context of a peace settlement.
So if you look at, for example, the insurgencies that we saw in Central America recently - El Salvador, Guatemala, what we've seen in Columbia.
In general, the insurgents and the governments make a kind of a peace treaty, and then it's when the notion of offering, granting, some degree of amnesty comes to the table.

What we see in Iraq here is really kind of an asymmetrical amnesty, which I really think goes into the symbolic issues that are at stake here as the Iraqis continue to struggle for some form of legitimacy and authority in what is a very, very complicated situation unfolding in the field.
